Tags: conjunction-elimination-2 math concept inference-rule

conjunction-elimination-2 (math concept)

See also

python declaration class | python inclusion class | python sample

Definition

conjunction-elimination-2 is the inference-rule:

\[\left( \boldsymbol{P} \land \mathbf{Q} \right) \vdash \mathbf{Q}\]

Where:

  • \(\boldsymbol{P} \land \mathbf{Q}\) is a formula-statement

  • \(\boldsymbol{P}\) is a propositional formula

  • \(\mathbf{Q}\) is a propositional formula

In straightforward language, if both \(\boldsymbol{P}\) and \(\mathbf{Q}\) are true, it follows that \(\mathbf{Q}\) is true.

Synonyms

  • Simplification [CCM14, p. 369]

Sources

  • [War18, p. 114]

  • [CCM14, p. 369]
